entry.title: See France's Basque coast through the eyes of a photographer
entry.summary:
The harbour at St-Jean-de-Luz offers a view to Ciboure, south of Biarritz, where the town and its neighbours retain a nostalgic charm. The pearl of France‚Äôs Basque coast, Biarritz has long been a playground for European high society. Today, the town and its neighbours retain a nostalgic charm, with visitors drawn to the region for fine dining, belle epoque architecture and surf breaks.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). The couple‚Äôs summertime sojourns made the belle √©poque-era seaside town popular with European royalty. But crowns and tiaras could not outshine the land‚Äôs unique Basque heritage, evident in its language, artistic expression and food culture. Basque cuisine remains popular to this day, from the traditional bakeries that‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòUnstable‚Äô asteroids lurk around Venus‚Äîis Earth at risk?
entry.summary:
Venus has groupies‚Äîa family of asteroids that share its orbit, either trailing it or leading it as the planet revolves around the sun. Researchers have known that such stealthy space rocks might exist for years, but now, a pair of papers (one published in a journal, and one a pre-print undergoing peer-review) conclude that some might develop unstable orbits and, over a very long period of time, arch toward Earth.
But despite what several histrionic headlines have claimed, Earth is not at risk of one of these asteroids suddenly sneaking up on us and vaporizing a city. While some of these asteroids could be large enough to cause this sort of damage, there is no evidence whatsoever suggesting any of these Venus-pursuing asteroids are currently heading our way.¬†
‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say that ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 169 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 28 to May 4, 2025. A total of 5,085 panelists responded out of 5,772 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: This report is made possible by The Pew Charitable Trusts. It is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at: pewresearch.org/science. Primary research team¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Eileen Yam, Director, Science and Society ResearchAlec Tyson, Associate Director, Science and Society ResearchBrian Kennedy, Senior ResearcherGiancarlo Pasquini, Research AssociateEmma Kikuchi, [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Americans‚Äô interest in purchasing electric and hybrid vehicles
entry.summary: The electric vehicle market in the U.S. continues to expand, albeit at a slower pace than earlier in the decade. One-third of Americans say they would very or somewhat seriously consider purchasing an electric vehicle (EV) as their next vehicle. This is a slight uptick from last year (4 percentage points), but still down from [‚Ä¶] The post 2. Americans‚Äô interest in purchasing electric and hybrid vehicles appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views on Trump administration energy policies and priorities
entry.summary: The Trump administration has taken a number of actions to promote the development and use of fossil fuels and reduce support for renewable energy. This includes a push to increase drilling for oil and natural gas on federal lands and an executive order pausing approvals and permits for wind energy projects, including offshore wind. Where [‚Ä¶] The post 1. Views on Trump administration energy policies and priorities appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans‚Äô Views on Energy at the Start of Trump‚Äôs Second Term
entry.summary: Americans have become less supportive of wind and solar power since the first Trump administration, a shift driven by declines in support among Republicans. The post Americans‚Äô Views on Energy at the Start of Trump‚Äôs Second Term appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: AIDS still killing one person every minute as funding cuts stall progress
entry.summary: AIDS-related deaths have dropped to their lowest level since 2004, but progress remains precarious, with the disease still claiming one life every minute. The impact of funding cuts is severe, causing widespread disruption to HIV services and threatening hard-won gains.

entry.summary: As hostilities rage in Sudan, access constraints and devastating funding cuts are isolating rape survivors and pregnant women from essential health services, the UN sexual and reproductive health agency UNFPA said on Thursday.

entry.title: Niassa was conservation paradise. Then ISIS attacked.
entry.summary: Just after 7 p.m. on the evening of April 29, conservation ecologist Colleen Begg was having dinner with her husband, Keith, and their two teenage children when her phone beeped with a WhatsApp message: The Mariri Environmental Centre she had founded in Mozambique‚Äôs Niassa Special Reserve had been attacked by terrorists. Two thousand people from a nearby village had fled into the bush. Begg spent a sleepless night organizing rescue efforts, but by morning she confronted a grim reality. Five of the ranger scouts on her team were missing, and a conservation dream she and Keith had spent more than 20 years nurturing was on the brink of collapse. The reserve is one of the last refuges for the critically endangered African wild dog, with some 300 of them roaming Niassa‚Äôs plains. The d‚Ä¶

entry.title: Sinful. Poisonous. Stinky? How tomatoes overcame a wicked history
entry.summary:
Once called the "poison apple," tomatoes were thought to be supernatural and sinful‚Äîespecially because of their red color. Tomatoes were reviled for centuries‚Äîso how did we come to embrace them? This small New Jersey town claims to have played a major role.
While Salem, Massachusetts gets all the hype for its infamous 1692 witch trials, there‚Äôs another city called Salem‚Äîthis time in New Jersey‚Äîthat‚Äôs tied to a rather legendary tale where tomatoes were the enemy.
(Witch hunts were common in the 17th century. Here‚Äôs what made Salem infamous.)
There are many myths and legends about how the tomato was once seen as the so-called ‚Äúpoison apple,‚Äù but how it lost its evil reputation and became a beloved piece of produce is a complicated story. According to historian Andrew F. Sm‚Ä¶

entry.title: These sky-high climbing routes are popping up in U.S. cities
entry.summary:
These climbing routes can be found throughout Europe, and now they can be found in‚Äîor near‚ÄîU.S. cities, too. Once reserved for mountain towns, iron-rung climbing courses called via ferratas are showing up in places like Columbus, Ohio. Here‚Äôs where else to try one.
You may not expect to find a 100-foot-tall limestone climbing course within minutes of a bustling city center, but that‚Äôs exactly what‚Äôs on offer at Quarry Trails Metro Park in Columbus, Ohio‚Äîhome to the first urban via ferrata in the country.¬†
Via ferratas are a combination of a ropes course and rock climbing. Harness-clad adventurers climb up and across sheer rock faces using iron rungs, steel cables, and vertiginous swinging bridges. The concept makes sky-high rock scaling feasible for those who lack technical ro‚Ä¶

entry.title: The best places to stay at Joshua Tree National Park
entry.summary:
During its long tenure as a national monument (1936-1994), Joshua Tree¬†was largely a do-it-yourself park where visitors had to fend for themselves, especially when it came to accommodation.¬†
Park brochures at that time explicitly stated, ‚ÄúNeither meals nor lodging are available in the Monument.‚Äù Campgrounds didn‚Äôt appear until the 1950s and they were very primitive, little more than a patch of sand with a picnic table.¬†
The turning point was Joshua Tree getting upgraded to national park status in 1994. Ever since, the accommodation situation has continued to improve. Camping is still the only way to sleep inside the park. But the range of overnight options in the gateway towns of Yucca Valley, Joshua Tree, and Twentynine Palms has undergone a quantum leap.¬†¬†¬†¬†

entry.title: Why three-toed sloths risk their lives to help moths
entry.summary:
For centuries, people encountering sloths for the first time have reacted by ridiculing them. In 1526, Spanish conquistador¬†Gonzalo Fern√°ndez de Oviedo y Vald√©s¬†wrote that the sloths he‚Äôd seen in the American tropics were ‚Äúugly,‚Äù ‚Äúuseless,‚Äù and ‚Äúthe stupidest animal that can be found in the world.‚Äù In 1749, French naturalist Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon, called them¬†‚Äúthe lowest form of existence‚Äù and judged that ‚Äúone more defect would have made their lives impossible.‚Äù
Harsh words about a creature that‚Äôs survived¬†for at least 50 million years.¬† Sloths have moth buddies who live with themThe more moths a sloth has, the more algae it has in its fur. In turn, the algae camouflages the sloth. Yes, sloths have poor hearing and eyesight,¬†and they're slow‚Äîthe slowest mamm‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 family-friendly things to do in Joshua Tree
entry.summary:
Keeping kids engaged and entertained at Joshua Tree National Park is often a matter of simple pleasures like camping in the desert, watching the heavens through a microscope, or scrambling between giant boulders at Skull Rock, Heart Rock, and other stony outcrops.¬†Here are 10 things to do in Joshua Tree with kids.
Hiking is one of the easiest activities for families to dive into. Unless you‚Äôre going to hike at dusk or dawn, it‚Äôs advisable to avoid marching the kids through the park‚Äôs triple-digit summer heat. Be sure to sync the hike‚Äôs length and difficulty level with their age and trekking experience.¬†
Among the park‚Äôs kid-friendly short hikes are Cholla Cactus Garden, the Oasis of Mara, Keys View with its mile-high panoramic views of the Coachella Valley, the slot canyons of ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Everything to know about Joshua Tree National Park
entry.summary:
Southern California's Joshua Tree National Park is best known for its iconic flora. The park straddles the Colorado Desert and the Mojave Desert, and features Keys View, which overlooks the famed Coachella Valley‚Äîbut there's much more to explore. Arid low desert and vegetated high desert meet in this beloved natural gem, offering visitors stunning vistas and rewarding hikes.
Joshua Tree National Park is often described as an out-of-this-world experience or healing for one‚Äôs soul, says Donovan Smith, the park‚Äôs public information officer. ‚ÄúWith blue sunny skies almost year-round, the wide-open vistas allow the visitor to experience the true vastness of the landscape from almost anywhere in the park. It‚Äôs an extraordinary place to connect with the beauty and reliance nature has to of‚Ä¶

entry.title: A complete guide to hiking in Joshua Tree National Park
entry.summary:
Like many national parks, Joshua Tree National Park offers a¬†wide range of trails¬†at all levels of hiking expertise and ability. No matter which route you choose or time of year you decide to visit, always remember that this national park is a desert.
Sunscreen, a hat, ample water, and a flashlight for night hikes are required even on shorter hikes. On longer jaunts, pack energy snacks, and a portable first-aid kit in case you have an unexpected run-in with a cactus or wildlife. Due to the lack of reliable cell phone service in the park, download your hiking route to GPS before setting off.

Hike these 'coffin roads' for an unmatched view of Scotland
entry.summary:
Coffin roads were used throughout the Scottish Highlands and Islands to carry caskets on foot to cemeteries with burial rites. In the Highlands and Islands, trace the steps of historic funeral processions through epic landscapes on some of Scotland‚Äôs most intriguing hikes.
Across abandoned expanses of Scotland‚Äôs wildest terrain, ancient footpaths chart a nearly forgotten history: Hundreds of mourners trudging from coasts and valleys, shouldering corpses in caskets for many miles. Over tall mountains, through rivers and woodlands, never letting the body touch the ground. Steeped in premonitions and superstition, these treks were a rural culture‚Äôs oldest death rites. Now, they‚Äôre some of the most unique hikes you can take.
Corpse, or coffin roads, were used throughout the Scotti‚Ä¶

entry.title: 5 of the best new cookbooks for summer
entry.summary: Dalmatia: Recipes from Croatia's Mediterranean Coast by Ino Kuvaƒçiƒá; Sama Sama by Julie Lin; Peach Street to Lobster Lane by Felicity Cloake; Smoke and Seasoned Bread by Hasan Semay; Pakistan by Maryam Jillani. Explore century-old Pakistani dishes, the stories behind US specialities and Dalmatia's coastal cuisine with these five new cookbooks to enjoy for the season. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). With more than 3,600 miles of coastline, Croatia‚Äôs Dalmatia region is intrinsically tied to the sea. This is apparent in its cuisine, where fish and seafood plucked directly from the Adriatic reigns supreme, whether it‚Äôs delicately sweet and silky oysters or smoky grilled sea bream. Melbourne-based restaura‚Ä¶

entry.title: The astonishing superpowers of nature‚Äôs most unloved animals
entry.summary:
Found across every continent except Antarctica and Australia, vultures like the lappet-faced species have lived among humans for millennia. But because they feast on the remains of dead animals, they‚Äôve been saddled with a reputation for carrying disease. Quite the contrary: By devouring rotting flesh, these scavengers prevent the spread of pathogens that cause bubonic plague, anthrax, and other diseases. They even stop carrion from emitting tens of millions of metric tons of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere each year. We owe a lot to this feathered cleanup crew. From their odd appendages to their unsavory hygiene, certain animals suffer an image problem. But their awkward attributes can be their biggest advantages.
The vulture has to be¬†one of the most reviled creatures on Ear‚Ä¶

entry.title: MSG is making a comeback. Was it ever really that bad for you?
entry.summary:
Monosodium glutamate, or MSG, is a common ingredient across Asian cuisines. But its history is riddled with false health claims and misinformation. For years, advertising and media connected the ingredient to ‚ÄúChinese Restaurant Syndrome.‚Äù Here‚Äôs what led to the misconception‚Äîand how MSG is being reclaimed today.
MSG‚Äôs reputation has been on the mend for years. Once blamed for dubious health concerns like headaches, numbness, and chest pains, the ingredient now appears in cocktails, cookies, and influencer pantry tours with growing pride.
But MSG‚Äôs cultural redemption hasn‚Äôt happened in a vacuum. Ajinomoto‚Äîthe world‚Äôs largest producer of monosodium glutamate, or MSG‚Äîhas played a quiet but consistent role in reshaping how we think about the additive. And a wave of Asian America‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan a self-drive boat tour of Ireland's River Shannon
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Irish heartlands put the emerald in the Emerald Isle ‚Äî and the River Shannon, which flows from County Cavan to County Kerry, is its lifeblood. It takes its name from the Celtic goddess Sinann: legend tells that she lifted the cover of a forbidden well in the Cavan Mountains, causing a flood to burst forth. Her drowned life force ebbed into the river she‚Äôd made, creating flower-filled meadows, tousled islands and fertile fields.
Cruising has long been a wonderful way to explore the Shannon ‚Äî the longest river in Ireland ‚Äî but now there‚Äôs more reason than ever to try it as the river‚Äôs boat fleet has been converted to hydro-treated vegetable oil (HVO) fuel, cutting carbon emissions by 92%. entry.title: Watch cockatoos figure out a water fountain
entry.summary: In suburban Sydney, sulphur-crested cockatoos (Cacatua galerita) previously figured out how to break into garbage bins and have now deciphered human water fountains.  Sulphur-crested cockatoos have previously mastered garbage bins. Now, it‚Äôs water fountains. Australia‚Äôs sulphur-crested cockatoos are bringing a new meaning to the term ‚Äúbird-brained,‚Äù one innovation at a time. A few years ago, it was opening garbage bins to find food, a practice birds across dozens of neighborhoods eventually adopted. But now, the social birds are lining up, waiting their turns, and drinking straight from water fountains in a Sydney park. And, according to researchers, it‚Äôs just the latest evidence of cockatoo ‚Äúculture.‚Äù ‚ÄúThese birds, they constantly surprise me,‚Äù says Barbara Klump,‚Ä¶

entry.title: How conservation icon David Attenborough holds onto hope
entry.summary:
For seven¬†decades, Sir David Attenborough has traversed the globe to document the kaleidoscopic diversity of Earth‚Äôs ecosystems. At the age of 99, he‚Äôs narrated so many television programs that his voice has become synonymous with the wonder of the natural world. But in his long career full of wild encounters, one memory still stands out.
In 1957, when Attenborough was in his 30s, he traveled to a shallow warmwater cay on Australia‚Äôs Great Barrier Reef, where, for the first time in his life, he donned scuba gear to examine corals up close. ‚ÄúIt was a sort of sensory overload,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe countless tiny fish swimming between coral branches; the differences between the different coral structures. It opened up for me a whole new appreciation of the intricacies of life in the ocean.‚Äù ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How this supertiny crustacean makes life work
entry.summary: Kim Bernard, at left, is an expert on Antarctic krill, a species crucial to the health of the continent‚Äôs food chain. For a research expedition on the Schmidt Ocean Institute‚Äôs R.V. Falkor (too), she was joined by Rachel Kaplan, a colleague from Oregon State University. For the first time, Antarctic krill have been found on seafloor vents. One scientist is working to figure out what they are doing there. Reporting in this article is presented by the National Geographic Society in partnership with Rolex under the National Geographic and Rolex Perpetual Planet Ocean Expeditions. entry.title: The world‚Äôs oceans are dying. Can a UN summit in Nice turn the tide?
entry.summary: As coral reefs bleach, fish stocks collapse, and sea temperatures break records, world leaders are heading to the French Riviera ‚Äî not for leisure, but for one of the most urgent diplomatic gatherings of the year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Top UN advocate sounds alarm over sexual violence crisis in gang-ravaged Haiti
entry.summary: Haiti has been gripped by spiralling gang violence ever since the 2021 assassination of President Jovenel Mo√Øse. The subsequent unrest has displaced one million people, more than half of them children,¬†according to the International Organization for Migration (IOM).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US vetoes Security Council resolution demanding permanent ceasefire in Gaza
entry.summary: A draft resolution calling for an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza failed to pass in the UN Security Council on Wednesday after the United States cast its veto ‚Äì blocking the initiative backed by all ten elected members of the Council.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Ambassadors to vote on new ceasefire resolution
entry.summary: After weeks of negotiations, the Council‚Äôs ten elected members have initiated a new draft resolution on Gaza as the humanitarian crisis deepens by the day. It calls for an immediate, unconditional and permanent ceasefire, the unconditional release of hostages held by Hamas and others and the immediate lifting of all aid restrictions. We‚Äôre joining live coverage from our Meetings Coverage Section and UN News app users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Environment Day: UN sounds alarm on plastic pollution crisis
entry.summary: Every year, 400 million tonnes of plastic are produced worldwide, according to the UN. Half of this plastic is designed to be used only once, and only 10 per cent is recycled.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: United States, Ukraine among new members elected to UN Economic and Social Council
entry.summary: The General Assembly on Wednesday elected a new slate of members to the UN Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), the principal body responsible for coordinating the Organization‚Äôs work on sustainable development and economic issues.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòOur worst held fears are being confirmed‚Äô: Dozens of bodies discovered in Libya mass graves
entry.summary: Dozens of bodies have been discovered at official and unofficial detention sites in Libya. The grim findings confirm deep concerns about abuse and torture at the facilities, according to the UN human rights chief Volker T√ºrk.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN relief chief welcomes growing support for aid teams to resume vital work
entry.summary: Amid reports of yet another deadly attack on a school in Gaza on Wednesday, the UN‚Äôs top aid official Tom Fletcher welcomed growing international calls for lifesaving aid work by established agencies to resume in the war-torn enclave.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The data is from a survey of 998 Israeli adults conducted face to face from February 5 to March 11, 2025. Interviews were conducted in Hebrew and Arabic, and the survey is representative of the adult population ages 18 and older, excluding those in East Jerusalem and in outposts that are not sanctioned by the [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Maria Smerkovich, Research AssociateKelsey Jo Starr, Former Research AnalystAndrew Prozorovsky, Research Assistant Laura Clancy, Research AnalystAlan Cooperman, Director, Religion ResearchRachel (Weisel) Drian, Associate Director, CommunicationsJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherMoira Fagan, Research AssociateJanell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood, Digital Production ManagerAnna Jackson, [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Views of Israeli and Palestinian political leaders
entry.summary: Israelis' views of Netanyahu, Gantz and Lapid lean negative, and they have especially unfavorable views of Palestinian leaders. The post 4. Views of Israeli and Palestinian political leaders appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. The role of the international community
entry.summary: Israelis broadly agree that the U.S. is helpful in the work toward lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians, and that Iran is harmful. The post 3. The role of the international community appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of obstacles to peace
entry.summary: Most Israelis see lack of trust between Israelis and Palestinians and the status of Jerusalem as major obstacles to lasting peace. The post 2. Views of obstacles to peace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views of the potential for lasting peace
entry.summary: 56% of Israelis say their people are committed to lasting peace, but fewer say this of the Palestinian people or the leaders on either side. The post 1. Views of the potential for lasting peace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Israeli Public Is Increasingly Skeptical About Lasting Peace
entry.summary: 21% of Israelis think Israel and a Palestinian state can coexist peacefully, the lowest share since 2013. The post Israeli Public Is Increasingly Skeptical About Lasting Peace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Volcano tourism is booming, but is it too risky?
entry.summary:
On June 2, 2025, Italy‚Äôs Mount Etna, one of Earth‚Äôs most active volcanoes, erupted again, releasing what experts called a ‚Äúlava fountain‚Äù that sent tourists rushing downhill to safety.
In late March 2021, thousands of people in Iceland hiked into the Geldingadalur valley to watch fiery lava splutter and spill from the crater of the Fagradalsfjall volcano after it erupted for the first time in nearly 800 years.
As white ash clouds puffed above trails of glowing, molten rock inching through craggy black stones, some visitors took photos, others sat in quiet awe, and a few toasted marshmallows over the lava flows.
Photographer Chris Burkard, who captured the eruption for National Geographic, was transfixed by the ominous-but-beautiful landscape too. ‚ÄúIt was mesmerizing,‚Äù he say‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 of the best state parks in Maine
entry.summary:
Parkgoers looking to avoid the crowds at Acadia National Park can visit Maine‚Äôs state parks, such as Quoddy Head State Park, home to the 3.6-mile Coastal Trail and the West Quoddy Head Lighthouse in Lubec. The state‚Äôs parks are often overshadowed by Acadia National Park‚Äîbut they shouldn‚Äôt be. These must-visit parks showcase the very best of the state‚Äôs natural wonders, from rugged coastlines and pristine wilderness.
In a state renowned for outstanding natural beauty and stunning landscapes, Acadia National Park, and Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument often overshadow Maine‚Äôs state parks, but they shouldn‚Äôt.
‚ÄúMaine‚Äôs state parks have everything: an iconic lighthouse guarding the bold coast at Quoddy Head, amazing beaches, and 4,000-foot mountains, like Old Speck and Ka‚Ä¶

entry.title: Japan‚Äôs Ryukyu Islands are a nature lovers‚Äô paradise
entry.summary:
The Ryukyu Islands are divided into three major island groups: Okinawa Islands, the Miyako Islands, and the Yaeyama Islands. The birthplace of karate also holds a deeply rooted connection to spirituality and nature. Here‚Äôs how to plan a visit to this stunning island archipelago.
As the legend goes, Japan‚Äôs Ryukyu Islands were created by the goddess Amamikyo, who is believed to have descended from the heavens and into the sea, just off the southern coast of what is now known as the main island of Okinawa.¬†
The Ryukyu Islands, located in the East China Sea, flourished for some 450-years as the semi-independent Ryukyu Kingdom. The islands served as a center of trade between Japan, China, and Southeast Asia until being officially designated a Japanese territory and renamed Okinawa‚Ä¶

entry.title: The essential guide to visiting Bermuda
entry.summary:
Bermuda features rich cultural traditions, historical landmarks, not-to-be-missed natural wonders, and more, making it the ideal tropical getaway for all types of travelers. World-class hotels, pink sand beaches, and lively year-around events make Bermuda a must-visit destination for any traveler.
Bermuda‚Äôs famed pink sand beaches have drawn travelers to its shores for decades. Still, travelers shouldn‚Äôt miss the rich cultural traditions, historical landmarks, and annual events that are just as alluring. The 21-square-mile island encompasses neighborhoods and natural wonders that provide enough options to inspire any trip.¬†
Summer:¬†Join the bacchanalia of Bermuda‚Äôs annual Carnival celebration in June. Parties commence on boats and in the streets with soca music and regga‚Ä¶

entry.title: Learning to live with the 800-pound bear next door
entry.summary:
The Mushkoh Valley in the north Indian region of Ladakh snakes twenty miles along mighty peaks near a contentious border. ¬†¬†
Small villages of farmers and pastoralists dot the valley floor, all home to people of the Shina culture who trace their ancestry to the Mediterranean and Alexander the Great‚Äôs campaigns into central Asia over two thousand years ago.
Snow leopards, Tibetan wolves, foxes, ibex, and blue sheep live throughout the mountainous valley that enters a snow-covered deep freeze in the winter and becomes blanketed by vibrant wild tulips during the summer.
The valley is a natural paradise, but scattered shrapnel remains hidden underfoot and memories of conflict linger. In 1999, the quiet mountain valley garnered global attention when it became the frontline for th‚Ä¶

entry.summary: As the hurricane season gets underway in the Caribbean, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) is sounding the alarm over Haiti‚Äôs humanitarian situation.

entry.title: World News in Brief: Aid for Syria, children under attack in Mozambique, rights-based climate action
entry.summary: Nearly 16 million people in Syria need urgent humanitarian health support, the UN warned on Tuesday, as aid deliveries continue amid escalating needs, deadly explosive hazards and a severe funding shortfall.

entry.title: Five humanitarians killed in ‚Äòhorrendous‚Äô attack on aid convoy in Sudan
entry.summary: An aid convoy carrying life-saving assistance for the famine-affected area of North Darfur, Sudan, was attacked on Monday night, killing five humanitarian workers, injuring many more and damaging critical humanitarian supplies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As displacement surges in South Sudan, regional humanitarian crisis deepens
entry.summary: Since a sharp escalation in fighting in South Sudan in late February, 165,000 people have fled their homes, seeking safety either within the country or across borders, the UN refugee agency UNHCR said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Rise in people fleeing to Chad as violence surges
entry.summary: The number of Sudanese refugees in Chad has more than tripled in just over two years amid the ongoing war in their homeland, the UN refugee agency UNHCR said in an alert on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Five countries elected to serve on UN Security Council
entry.summary: Bahrain, Colombia, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Latvia, and Liberia were elected on Tuesday to serve as non-permanent members of the UN Security Council, with two-year terms beginning in January 2026.

entry.title: Looking Back on Five Years: How the Sigma Awards Have Rallied and Inspired Data Journalism Excellence

entry.title: There‚Äôs now a 50-50 chance this galaxy will crash into ours
entry.summary:
For more than a century, astronomers have watched the Andromeda galaxy, a massive swirl of neighboring stars, speed toward the Milky Way. And in recent years, measurements using the Hubble Space Telescope seemed to confirm a long-held prophecy: In about four or five billion years‚Äô time, the two galaxies will clash, ultimately merging into a colossal and unrecognizable new galaxy.
A fresh survey of both galaxies and‚Äîcrucially‚Äîseveral of the other weighty galaxies in the same corner of the cosmos has now cast doubt on that calamitous outcome. The new forecast looked billions of years into the future and found that the odds of an Andromeda and Milky Way merger is about fifty-fifty.¬†
‚ÄúA coin flip is the more accurate description,‚Äù says Till Sawala, an astrophysicist at the University‚Ä¶

entry.title: Queen Victoria loved this UK island‚Äîand so will you
entry.summary:
A keen walker, poet Alfred Lord Tennyson was known for cutting a dash in his distinctive black cloak over the westerly downs, where you‚Äôll find hiking trails and a grand monument named in his honour. One-time haunt of Queen Victoria, the Isle of Wight has a host of unique charms, including dramatic sea stacks and a thriving population of red squirrels.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Package all that‚Äôs wonderful ‚Äî and quite frankly quirky ‚Äî about England, set it adrift in the English Channel, and you‚Äôll end up with the Isle of Wight. A UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, it‚Äôs the UK‚Äôs largest island and a microcosm of its heritage ‚Äî all thatched cottages, centuries-old pubs and undulating landscapes. Some of the Victorian era‚Äôs most influential figure‚Ä¶

entry.title: Photo story: uncovering the charm of Bermuda
entry.summary: undefined undefined Bermuda's distinctive "boiler" reefs, seen here near the South Shore Beaches, create a churning effect in the water that resembles boiling. Bermuda sees an influx of part-time residents in the spring and summer: Longtails. These black-and-white tropicbirds, named for their long feathered tails, spend the winter at sea and return to Bermuda from March through August to nest in its cliffs and crevices. The traditional Gombey costume features a peacock feather headdress, painted mask, bells, and tassels, but each dancer adds their own twist to the ensemble. The word "Gombey" is thought to come from an African term meaning "rhythm," highlighting the role of drumming and percussive beats in their performances. undefined undefined For a bird‚Äôs-eye view of Bermuda‚Äôs reefs, landmarks, and distinctive fishhook shape, visitors can take to the skies with Heather Nicholds, owner of Blue Sky Flights. Nicholds offers 25-minute discovery flights and 45-minute full sightseeing tours around the island in her small plane. The view underground is equally stunning. In Bermuda‚Äôs East End, the Crystal and Fantasy Caves invite visitors to explore the island‚Äôs subterranean wonders.

entry.title: A practical guide to island-hopping in Croatia
entry.summary:
Croatia's coastline is ideal for exploring by boat - smaller vessels can more easily access the Dalmatian islands' many hidden coves. With over 1,000 islands and an efficient ferry system, the Mediterranean country is a great island-hopping destination for travellers with time to spare. For tips on how to do it, try this handy guide.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). Island-hopping is a charming way to discover Croatia, allowing you to enjoy shots of espresso and shimmering sea views on deck as you sail from coast to coast. National ferry operator Jadrolinija and private competitors link most inhabited islands in the country. The majority of inter-island trips run during the daytime and vary in length from just 20 minutes to a few ho‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this shopping mall the gayest place on Earth?
entry.summary:
Opened in 1982, the Yumbo Centrum in Spain's Canary Island bills itself as the world‚Äôs only LGBTQ+ mall. With four floors and 200 venues across 200,000 square feet, the Yumbo anchors a queer community remaking travel as a double-down embrace of their true selves. At the Yumbo Centrum in Spain's Canary Islands, Pride never ends.
Dario Villalba, 29,¬†a shirtless actuary from Milan, roars into the night, jumping in a sweaty briar patch of¬†men on a far-flung Spanish island. ‚ÄúSempre! Sempre!‚Äù¬†he cheers. ‚ÄúSempre di pi√π! Yumbo per sempre!‚Äù (‚ÄúAlways and always! More and more! Yumbo forever!‚Äù) As a Bruno Mars remix blares, Villalba revamps the chorus: ‚ÄúSleep tomorrow, but tonight go crazy. All you gotta do is just meet me at the‚Äî'Yumbooooo.‚Äô‚Äù
Opened in 1982 with the hope of ‚Äúif you‚Ä¶

entry.title: World News in Brief: Guterres condemns antisemitic attacks, ILO to debate pros and cons of working online, Sudan, Ukraine updates
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Monday reinforced his stand against all acts of antisemitism following the horrific attack in Boulder, Colorado, at the weekend and vandalism in France targeting Jewish landmarks.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN calls for ‚Äòimmediate and unconditional‚Äô release of aid workers arbitrarily detained in Yemen
entry.summary: As June marks one year since the arbitrary detention of dozens of personnel from the UN, NGOs, civil society organizations and diplomatic missions by the Houthi de facto authorities in Yemen, the UN Secretary-General has reiterated his call for their release, urging they be¬†freed ‚Äúimmediately and unconditionally.‚Äù

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Deadly flooding in Nigeria displaces thousands
entry.summary: Flash flooding in western Nigeria at the weekend has caused devastation around the town of Mokwa in Niger state, leaving more than 150 dead and 3,000 people displaced ‚Äì more than half of whom are children aged 12 and under ‚Äì the UN said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Germany‚Äôs Annalena Baerbock elected President of the 80th General Assembly
entry.summary: Former German foreign minister Annalena Baerbock was elected President of the General Assembly‚Äôs 80th session on Monday. Her appointment comes as the regional group that includes Western Europe takes its turn at the helm of the world body.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Guterres urges probe into killings at food distribution sites
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has called for an investigation into the killing and injury of Palestinians seeking food aid in Gaza on Sunday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine‚Äôs frontline families struggle to cultivate mined fields amid conflict
entry.summary: As Ukrainian and Russian delegations meet for a second round of preliminary peace talks in Turk√Øye on Monday, rural communities¬†faced their own challenge: finding something to eat.

entry.title: Where to travel in July
entry.summary:
As schools go on holiday for the summer, July is the busiest month for travel in Europe. As the mercury rises and summer holidays commence, travel in July can be a family affair. And for those without young ones in tow, there are intrepid adventures to be had, from wildlife-watching in the Okavango Delta to seeing the Arctic tundra in bloom.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Let freedom ring: in July, European schools close for summer, marking the busiest month for travel on the continent. Cities buzz as people embrace the heat with outdoor cinemas and rooftop beer gardens, while ice cream vans sweeten up seaside towns. Families looking for sand and sea can beat the crowds by heading to the more serene European alternatives of Albania and Monte‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lifting of Israeli blockade ‚Äòthe only way to avert mass starvation‚Äô in Gaza: UNRWA chief
entry.summary: Amid disputed reports of Israeli forces firing on civilians near a new privatised aid distribution point in southern Gaza, the head of the Palestine refugee agency, UNRWA, said on Sunday that lifting the months-long aid blockade of the enclave is the only way to avoid ‚Äúmass starvation‚Äù.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Helpless in the face of hunger: Gaza families pray for deliverance ‚Äì or death
entry.summary: ‚ÄúI stood helpless in the face of my son's hunger. I cried a lot and told him to drink from our little water to satisfy his hunger,‚Äù said Zeenat, a young Palestinian woman speaking to UN News from the battered Gaza Strip.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As AI evolves, pressure mounts to regulate ‚Äòkiller robots‚Äô
entry.summary: A world in which algorithms determine the fate of soldiers and civilians alike is no longer hypothetical. AI-driven drones are reshaping warfare, raising deep ethical questions about autonomy in combat.¬†As international policymakers scramble to set ground rules, the race is on to rein in this rapidly evolving technology.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Is this Canadian festival the best place to see grey whales?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Stand on the western shores of Vancouver Island in March and you‚Äôll spot some of British Columbia‚Äôs most famous visitors. Each spring, thousands of grey whales glide past this stretch of coast on their journey from the warm breeding waters of Mexico to the nutrient-rich waters of Alaska ‚Äî a round trip of up to 15,000 miles, making it the longest mammal migration on Earth.
In the mid-1980s, Brian Congdon, a resident of Ucluelet on the west coast of Vancouver Island, had an idea. He wanted to celebrate this natural spectacle with a home-grown festival, much like those he‚Äôd seen in California. Drawing on his experience running a whale-watching tour company, he brought together volunteers and local authorities, devised‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why the Balkans should be your next summer destination
entry.summary:
To beat the crowds and chase adventure, plan a trip to the smaller, less-explored countries of the Western Balkans ‚Äî here are five to explore. The final frontier of Europe is this southeastern peninsula, where travellers can find Roman palaces, old Ottoman quarters, aquamarine bays and dramatic mountain hikes ‚Äî but far fewer crowds.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
A complicated region with an extraordinarily rich cultural heritage, Europe‚Äôs beautiful Balkan lands have been passed through and fought over by civilisations including the Romans, Greeks and Ottomans for more than a millennium. As a result, the term ‚ÄòBalkans‚Äô is one of the slipperiest geographical descriptions in Europe. Broadly speaking it applies to the peninsula that stretc‚Ä¶

entry.title: These 4,500-year-old rattles may be among the world‚Äôs oldest toys
entry.summary:
Archaeologist Mette Marie Hald holds fragments of 4,500-year-old rattles found at the Hama site in Syria. Hald and her colleagues suspect that the rattles and others like them were used to sooth children rather than to make music, as some have previously suggested. A new study argues that ancient rattles unearthed in Syria aren‚Äôt musical instruments, but toys used to entertain infants. ‚ÄúToday, we use screens, back then it was rattles.‚Äù
Clay rattles made in Syria about 4,500 years ago were designed to ‚Äúamuse and calm‚Äù infants, according to a new study. But some archaeologists think they were used in rituals to dispel evil spirits, or that they might have served both purposes.
‚ÄúThey have little handles that are too small for me, and I have quite small hands,‚Äù says archaeolo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Climbing Mount Everest may get even harder
entry.summary:
Mount Everest and Lhotse are seen through Buddhist prayer flags in Nepal. A new proposal from Nepal aims to tighten requirements and improve climber safety on the world's tallest peak, but such proposals rarely become law.
Last month, as the 2025 climbing season began on Mount Everest, Nepal‚Äôs upper house of Parliament introduced a tourism bill that includes a suite of new rules that would significantly raise the bar for who is allowed to attempt the mountain, who can guide, and how much it will cost.¬†¬†
This year‚Äôs proposal includes a mandate that Everest hopefuls must first climb a 7,000-meter peak located in Nepal, as well as requirements for all guides to be Nepalese citizens, for medical certificates confirming good health to be obtained from approved in-country facilities‚Ä¶

entry.title: How the Council of Nicaea changed Christianity forever
entry.summary:
This May marks 1,700 years since the convening of what is arguably the most important and influential council in Christian history. For three months in 325 CE, Emperor Constantine gathered hundreds of bishops from across the empire in Nicaea, on the northern coast of what is now Turkey. The resulting statement of belief‚Äîthe Nicene Creed‚Äîwas the first official declaration of Christian faith and remains foundational for Christians around the world to this day. Attend Sunday school or a Christian church of nearly any denomination, and you will encounter principles derived from the Nicene Creed.
The task of the council was enormous: to establish correct Christian doctrine, fix the date of Easter, define episcopal jurisdictions, and devise protocols for addressing local schisms and disse‚Ä¶

entry.title: You really are a mosquito magnet. Here‚Äôs what you can do.
entry.summary: Colored scanning electron micrograph of a female specimen of the mosquito species, Anopheles gambiae. This micrograph shows the mosquito's bulging abdomen, swollen after a meal of human blood. New research proves these bloodsuckers can pick you out in a crowd. Here are the odors they‚Äôre drawn to, what scientists recommend to keep them away‚Äîand how a future personalized repellant might work. Mosquitoes love Kim Zarins. The insects‚Äô preference for Zarins, an English professor at Sacramento State University, is so extreme that her 20-year-old son likes her to come outside with him because she serves as a decoy and ‚Äúhe knows he‚Äôll be safe,‚Äù Zarins says. But now, mosquito magnets like Zarins are helping scientists pinpoint what entices these thirsty bloodsuckers, and th‚Ä¶

entry.title: How this California Gold Rush town became an LGBTQ+ haven
entry.summary:
Since the early to mid-1800s, Nevada City has been a haven for many people in California and beyond, including LGBTQ+ travelers and transplants. Prospectors came to Nevada City for gold, but the forested community has become an enduring oasis for artists, musicians, and bohemians.
When the first settlers came to the Sierra Nevada foothills in the late 1840s, they came for gold. Decades after the California Gold Rush ended in 1855, a different crop of settlers‚Äîincluding artists, musicians, and LGBTQ+ people‚Äîcame looking for something other than precious metal.¬†
History runs deep in Nevada City, a hilly, pine-scented community of barely 3,000, which boomed in 1849 upon the arrival of¬†early settlers¬†like Captain John Pennington and William McCaig. During its heyday, miners came a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why June is the best month to visit this U.S. Virgin Island
entry.summary:
St. Thomas in June brings calmer waters, cheaper hotels, turtle sightings, and more room to stretch out. The best place in the Caribbean for a passport-free tropical escape offers up great weather, fewer crowds, and hotel rates up to half off in the shoulder season.
It turns out that the grass actually is¬†greener in St. Thomas‚Äîsea turtle grass, that is, for those traveling in June. This sweet spot, after the bustle and beats of carnival season concludes across most of the Caribbean, is both an ecologist‚Äôs paradise and a deal-hunter‚Äôs delight.
Canopies of fire-red flamboyant flowers¬†blanket the island, complementing the hue of mangoes that hang lush and ripe. Nesting season starts for green sea turtles, which are drawn not only to shore to lay their eggs, but to the shallow-wat‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 places to stay while you're at Yosemite National Park
entry.summary:
Situated at the base of a granite rock cliff, the Ahwahnee Hotel opened in 1927 and is an example of the National Park Service's rustic architecture, also known as ‚Äúparkitecture.‚Äù This hotel is just one of 10 incredible places to stay when visiting Yosemite National Park. Choose your own adventure: a rustic tent cabin at the base of Half Dome or a lavish lodge just outside the national park‚Äôs gate.
Yosemite National Park¬†welcomes approximately four million visitors every year. Not surprisingly, travelers from around the world are drawn to the 748,000 acres of natural beauty which include Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, El Capitan, Glacier Point, numerous waterfalls, and Mariposa Grove, where visitors can walk through a giant sequoia. With so much to see and do, visitors to the national‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Sally Ride blazed a trail for women in space
entry.summary:
Sally Ride sits in the aft flight deck mission specialist's seat during deorbit preparations. On June 18, 1983, Sally Ride became the first American woman to fly in space when the space shuttle Challenger launched on mission STS-7. As one of the three mission specialists on the mission, Ride played a vital role in helping the crew deploy communications satellites, conduct experiments, and make use of the first Shuttle Pallet Satellite. In June 1983, this barrier-breaking astronaut overcame discriminatory policies‚Äîand a sexist society‚Äîas the first American woman to launch into orbit.
On June 18, 1983, Sally Ride would become the first American woman to launch into space. She had already survived NASA's grueling training and a barrage of tests, but there was another hurdle to cross ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Earth‚Äôs Most Interesting Animals
entry.summary:
Before your visit, discover some of Earth's most captivating creatures found at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park, like the stealthy Sumatran tiger, the soaring California condor, and the resilient desert tortoise‚Äîeach with its own fascinating traits that you can observe during your safari adventure.
The southern white rhino, nearly 99 percent of which are found in South Africa, Kenya, Namibia, and Zimbabwe, is one of the largest land animals on Earth, second only to elephants. Despite the name, these rhinos are gray, and "white" was likely derived from the Afrikaans word for "wide," referring to their broad, square mouths. These semi-social animals often live in groups; males are usually solitary and mark their territory with dung. White rhinos are grazers, and enjoy rolling in mud‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòThis is not just ice‚Äô: Glaciers support human livelihoods, UN deputy chief says
entry.summary: UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed called for urgent action to protect water-related ecosystems in remarks to the International Conference on Glaciers‚Äô Preservation in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN‚Äôs lifesaving programmes under threat as budget crisis hits hard
entry.summary: The UN is facing a deepening budget crisis that threatens lifesaving operations worldwide. From refugee aid in Mozambique to maternal health services in Afghanistan, critical programmes are on the brink of collapse unless urgent funding is secured.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòJustice is long overdue‚Äô: Guterres calls for reparations for enslavement and colonialism
entry.summary: Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres renewed his calls for Member states and the United Nations to work towards justice and reparations for Africans and the diaspora in a speech in New York on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Education suffers amid DR Congo violence, WHO greenlights RSV vaccines, more hurricanes ahead for Haiti
entry.summary: In Ituri, a province in the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), intensifying conflict, intercommunal violence and mass displacement are forcing hundreds of thousands of children out of school.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Songs of hope rise from Gaza‚Äôs ruins
entry.summary: In Al-Jundi Al-Majhool Square ‚Äì once the bustling heart of Gaza City ‚Äì music now floats among the tents. The square, transformed into a sprawling displacement camp, shelters hundreds of families driven from their homes by more than 19 months of war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Flavoured nicotine products driving youth addiction, WHO warns
entry.summary: For most nicotine users today, their first experience with the drug is a flavoured product ‚Äì making it easier, and more appealing, to try.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza is the ‚Äòhungriest place on earth‚Äô, as Israel continues stranglehold on aid
entry.summary: Starving Gazans continue to be deprived of aid as international relief efforts are being severely constrained by the Israeli authorities, the UN humanitarian affairs coordination office OCHA said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate island-hopping adventure in Croatia
entry.summary:
Whatever you‚Äôre looking for, you‚Äôll find it in Croatia's islands ‚Äî from buzzy resorts for a party crowd on Hvar to towns like Korƒçula or Rab, their streets an insouciant jumble of gothic and Renaissance beauty. In between are endless pine-scrubbed specks with no firm grip on the 21st century, washed by the cleanest waters in the Mediterranean. Known as the land of a thousand islands, Croatia‚Äôs Dalmatia and Kvarner archipelagoes offer an abundance of coastal adventures ‚Äî from exploring a little-known National Park to swimming in a cave plucked from Odyssean legend.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The fascination of islands is that they appear to be distinct, self-contained worlds. If that‚Äôs true, then Croatia is practically its own solar syste‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why some people struggle to form mental images
entry.summary:
Close your eyes and imagine an apple.
Can you see its shape? What color is it? Is it floating in the air, or being held by a hand, or sitting on a table?
If you find yourself struggling, you might have arecently coined condition called aphantasia.¬†
People with aphantasia, or ‚Äúaphants,‚Äù say they lack the ability to effectively visualize in their mind‚Äôs eye. They might have vivid imaginations, and lead very creative lives, but their brains work a little differently when it comes to visual imagery.
Twenty-five years ago, Adam Zeman, a professor of cognitive and behavioral neurology previously at the University of Exeter, now an honorary fellow at the Centre for Clinical Brain Sciences in Edinburgh, was introduced to the curious case of a man who had lost the ability to vis‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to stay in Porto
entry.summary:
The Yeatman is one of many unique accommodation options in the Portuguese city of Porto. Portugal‚Äôs second city is riding a wave and its hotel scene is equal to the task, with wine-themed haunts up to palatial pads.


This article was adapted from National Geographic Traveller (UK) In a city dominated by independent hotels, Porto offers a plethora of unique and interesting boutique places to stay. From converted warehouses and 19th-century palaces to properties in and around the famous wine district, you‚Äôre ne‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who was Sacagawea? The real story of her life and legacy
entry.summary:
Explorer Sacagawea stares into the distance while Jean Baptiste Charbonneau sleeps soundly on her back. She was vital to the Lewis and Clark Expedition after the Louisiana Purchase. Often remembered merely for guiding Lewis and Clark, Sacagawea‚Äôs story is far more complex. Discover the deeper story behind the life of this Shoshone woman‚Äîbeyond the expedition.
Of all the figures that emerged from the¬†American West, none may be so wrapped in mythology as Sacagawea. When she joined Meriwether Lewis and William Clark's infamous expedition west, she was just a teenager and a new mother. However, Sacagawea emerged as an icon of the New World.
Today, her name is synonymous with a period characterized by rapid westward expansion at the great expense of the Tribal Nations who stewarde‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside Chile's wild and beautiful Juan Fern√°ndez Islands
entry.summary:
On a recent visit to Chile's Juan Fern√°ndez Islands, National Geographic photographer Andy Mann found himself surrounded by hundreds of playful locals: endemic Juan Fern√°ndez fur seals. Once thought to be extinct, the seals are believed to number more than 200,000, far exceeding the islands' human population of under a thousand. And the blubbery denizens are not shy about approaching divers.
"It's probably the most joyous, childlike diving I've ever done‚Äîlike getting in the water with 500 puppies," says Mann. "They're so curious and charismatic."
The dive was one of many highlights of Mann's trip to Juan Fern√°ndez, an archipelago of three islands teeming with endemic plants and animals ‚Äî including the seals, orange-feathered Juan Fern√°ndez firecrown hummingbirds, and two vulnerab‚Ä¶

author.name: Christina Nunez, Andy Mann, Kyle Roepke

entry.title: These destinations inspired the most popular video games
entry.summary: Valley of the Kings near Luxor, Egypt, is featured in popular video games such as Indiana Jones and the Great Circle and Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Origins, inspiring gamers to add the historic destination to their travel bucket list. Video game tourism is on the rise as the games‚Äô immersive and interactive worlds spark wanderlust in their biggest fans. From Oslo to Tokyo, here are eight places where gamers can level up. At least 35 percent of U.S. travelers are inspired to book a trip overseas based on a video game they've played, according to Skyscanner‚Äôs¬†recent survey As technology becomes more accessible and sophisticated, video games continue to gain points other traditional media can‚Äôt quite reach.¬†May Naidoo¬†is not surprised. He‚Äôs a filmmaker and Pok√©mon Partner w‚Ä¶

entry.title: Towel art has risen to a whole new level
entry.summary:
As any traveler can attest to, it‚Äôs the unique touches in hotel rooms and cruise cabins that make a trip that much more memorable. For both adults and children, there's nothing more uplifting than walking into your room to find a towel folded into the shape of a lovable animal. But how did the art form of origami make its way to the hospitality industry?
The history of origami is as complex as the intricately folded paper. Many scholars believe that the invention of paper in China, around 100 B.C.E., coincided with the first attempts at paper folding. It was the Japanese who made origami, originally known as orikata, a large part of their culture. Because paper was very expensive, the art form was mostly used for religious rituals by the wealthy, including wrapping offerings to the go‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 160 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Jan. 8-19, 2025, among a sample of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) U.S. adults. entry.title: 5. Community, friends and LGBTQ spaces
entry.summary: We asked LGBTQ Americans some questions to better understand: Connections to a broader LGBTQ community About a quarter of LGBTQ adults (23%) say they feel extremely or very connected to a broader LGBTQ community. Another 42% feel somewhat connected, and 35% feel not too or not at all connected. Views on this vary by: How [‚Ä¶] The post 5. Community, friends and LGBTQ spaces appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. LGBTQ identities
entry.summary: To better understand how LGBTQ adults identify, we asked respondents three separate questions: When it comes to sexual orientation, more than half of LGBTQ adults (55%) describe themselves as bisexual. Four-in-ten are gay or lesbian, while small shares are straight (1%) or something else (3%). About one-in-ten LGBTQ adults (9%) are transgender. This includes 4% [‚Ä¶] The post 4. LGBTQ identities appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Experiences with coming out as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender
entry.summary: To better understand the coming out experiences of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender adults, we asked them: Half or more in each group say they knew they were gay, lesbian, bisexual or trans before age 14. Far fewer say they first told someone by that age. Small shares ranging from 1% to 4% across these [‚Ä¶] The post 3. Experiences with coming out as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Personal experiences with acceptance and discrimination
entry.summary: We asked LGBTQ adults whether they feel accepted by their family, friends and co-workers, and about their experiences with discrimination based on their LGBTQ identity. Some LGBTQ adults are not out to different people in their lives. Varying shares say no one in each of the following groups knows about their sexual orientation or gender [‚Ä¶] The post 2. entry.title: Ukraine: Hopes for peace on life support, Security Council hears
entry.summary: A glimmer of hope for peace in Ukraine has been overshadowed by a devastating new wave of Russian attacks, UN officials told the Security Council on Thursday, warning of soaring civilian casualties and a worsening humanitarian crisis that could derail a diplomatic end to the war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN searches for solutions to global housing crisis
entry.summary: The UN‚Äôs urban development agency¬†estimates that an astonishing 2.8 billion people worldwide lack access to adequate housing, secure land, and basic water and sanitation services ‚Äì that‚Äôs around 40 per cent of the global population.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòWe are the present‚Äô: Tajik climate activist urges leaders to include youth voices in dialogue
entry.summary: A young activist from Tajikistan is speaking up to show that her generation can be part of the solution to combat climate change.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Desperate hunger drives crowd to storm UN food warehouse in Gaza
entry.summary: Desperate hunger drove crowds of people to overrun a World Food Programme (WFP) warehouse in central Gaza on Wednesday, reportedly leaving two dead and several injured in a chaotic scramble for food.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN honours service and sacrifice of its peacekeepers
entry.summary: The United Nations is honouring staff serving at its field missions through several events to mark the International Day of UN Peacekeepers on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Winners revealed: National Geographic Traveller (UK) Photography Competition 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
¬†Seeking to highlight the best in travel photography, this prestigious annual competition, celebrating its 12th year, was open to entrants from across the UK and Ireland. Photographers, both amateur and professional, submitted travel images taken during the past year in any of six categories: Landscape, People, Wildlife, Food, City life and Portfolio.¬†
Pat Riddell, editor of National Geographic Traveller (UK), said: ‚ÄúOur competition goes from strength to strength, with this year‚Äôs easily one of the strongest yet. World-class photography remains at the heart of the National Geographic brand, and the winners happily sit in that category.¬†
‚ÄúCapturing everything from the dramatic landscapes of Iceland and Italy to‚Ä¶

entry.title: Tips for Turning Unreadable Text Into Evidence
entry.summary: Whether it's extracting names from footage, decoding social media posts, or reading distorted text in documents, Henk van Ess explains how free digital tools can take on these investigative tasks.

entry.title: Video: How religious are young Americans today?
entry.summary: Young adults today are less religious than older adults by traditional measures. But when it comes to spirituality, the differences are smaller. The post Video: How religious are young Americans today? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 9 celestial events lighting up the night sky this June
entry.summary:
Whether you‚Äôre waking up early to spot Venus in the pre-dawn sky, staying up late to peep the Lagoon Nebula, or spending the whole night on the hunt for meteors, June‚Äôs night sky has something for every stargazer. Here‚Äôs what to keep an eye out for when you look up this month.
(9 must-see night sky events to look forward to in 2025.)
On June 1, Venus will reach its farthest distance west of the sun from the perspective of Earth‚Äîa point known as greatest western elongation. This is a particularly good time to get a glimpse at Earth‚Äôs neighboring planet, as it won‚Äôt be drowned out by sunlight.
In some time zones, the exact timing of this event occurs on May 31, while in others, it's on June 1. But the best time to view Venus is just before dawn, when it rises in the eastern ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Need to unwind? This new travel trend adds a twist.
entry.summary:
Taking action to restore and care for nature sparks the brain‚Äôs reward circuits, fostering a lasting sense of purpose and connection. Wellness-centric travel has long been popular, with numerous health studies touting the benefits of spending more time in nature. A new evolution of the trend puts wildlife at the center‚Äîresponsibly.
In today‚Äôs fast-paced and tech-dominated world, people are plugged into the conveniences of modern day life, but they‚Äôre as disconnected as ever, overlooking the simple joys of nature and the wellness benefits it can offer us. You could say that the more high-tech we become, the more nature we undoubtedly need. The practice of forest bathing to cultivate relaxation and ward off the effects of stress and anxiety is well-established, but next-level nature ‚Ä¶

entry.title: These are the best stargazing sites in North America
entry.summary:
Both urban and rural areas are darkening their skies to boost astrotourism. These dark sky sanctuaries, reserves, parks, and trails invite you to immerse yourself in the wonders of our night skies. Here‚Äôs where to go.
Travelers are increasingly lifting their eyes to nighttime skies in search of impressive celestial phenomena and, perhaps, more. ‚ÄúLooking up at the night sky is sort of what makes us human,‚Äù says Ruskin Hartley, the executive director of DarkSky International, a nonprofit group based in Tucson, Arizona. ‚ÄúWe have done it for millennia. Every single culture has told their first stories in the stars overhead, and they found meaning in the stars. Today, the vast majority of people are robbed of that.‚Äù
On a clear night last November, I spent over two hours in a dome a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explore the UK through its family-friendly summer festivals
entry.summary:
Sewing camps and sensory gardens will be at this year‚Äôs Camp Bestival. Music festivals in the UK are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Here are this summer‚Äôs family-friendly highlights.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Music festivals are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Younger audiences are often won over purely by the fact that attendance typically involves camping, glamping or pitching up in a caravan ‚Äî an opportunity to sleep out in the wild. But the UK‚Äôs best festivals also provide an endless roster of activities, workshops and experiences to help families bond and create lasting memories. From chilled countryside escapes to adrenaline-sparking coastal adventures. Here are the golden tickets‚Ä¶

entry.title: The world‚Äôs plastic pollution crisis, explained
entry.summary:
Plastic trash drifts in the ocean in the Philippines. Much of the planet is swimming in discarded plastic, which is harming animal and possibly human health. Can plastic pollution be cleaned up?
Plastic pollution has become one of the most pressing environmental issues, thanks to the overwhelming rise in production of disposable plastic products.
Plastic pollution is most visible in developing Asian and African nations, where garbage collection systems are often inefficient or nonexistent. But the developed world, especially in countries with low recycling rates, also has trouble properly collecting discarded plastics.
Plastic trash has become so ubiquitous it has prompted efforts to write a global treaty negotiated by the United Nations.
Plastics made from fossil ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Pandemics to pollution: WHO Assembly delivers landmark health decisions
entry.summary: The 78th World Health Assembly concluded Tuesday in Geneva, marking several major milestones in global health. Delegates adopted the world‚Äôs first pandemic agreement and approved a significant boost in core funding for the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war exacerbates risk of cholera and malaria: UNICEF
entry.summary: The UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) has warned of an escalating public health crisis in Sudan, as conflict and mass displacement continue to drive a surge in disease, particularly cholera and malaria.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: UN warns against Houthi-Israel escalation, calls for dialogue
entry.summary: The United Nations has called for restraint following another wave of escalation between Houthi rebels in Yemen and Israeli forces.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN awards 2025 Mandela Prize to Brenda Reynolds and Kennedy Odede
entry.summary: An Indigenous¬†social worker from Canada and a social entrepreneur from Kenya are the laureates of the 2025 Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela Prize, the United Nations announced on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòMy husband died in my arms‚Äô: Russian drone attacks on Ukrainians amount to crimes against humanity, UN investigators report
entry.summary: Russian drone attacks against civilians in the Kherson region of Ukraine constitute crimes against humanity and war crimes, independent UN human rights investigators concluded in a report published on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòWe are women like you‚Äô: UN honours peacekeepers for work in gender empowerment
entry.summary: In early summer 2024, Squadron Leader Sharon Mwinsote Syme of Ghana ventured into sector North of Abyei, a disputed region between Sudan and South Sudan where she was deployed as a military gender advocate with the UN Interim Security Force in Abyei (UNISFA).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Top UN envoy calls on Israel to end devastating strikes, starvation of civilians
entry.summary: Gaza‚Äôs population is being ‚Äústarved and denied the very basics,‚Äù while the region stands at a dangerous crossroads, the UN‚Äôs Middle East peace envoy warned the Security Council Wednesday, urging immediate action to halt the violence, restore aid and advance a two-State solution before time runs out.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aid teams plead for access amid reports Gazans shot collecting food
entry.summary: In Gaza, dozens of Palestinians have been reportedly injured and shot trying to collect aid from the new US and Israeli-backed aid distribution facility operating independently of the UN.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate change: World likely to breach 1.5¬∞C limit in next five years
entry.summary: Fact: 2024 was the warmest year on record ‚Äì but the heat is far from over. A new report from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warns that global temperatures will likely continue rising, with an 80 per cent chance that at least one year between now and 2029 will be even hotter.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How did this shark swim a record-breaking 4,000 miles?
entry.summary:
Bull sharks tend to be aggressive and live near shorelines, which has earned them fearsome reputations. One eight-foot-long female recently logged a record breaking 4,000-mile journey. Along her migration from Mozambique to Nigeria, the eight-foot-long female would have encountered a zone of water too cold to cross that has kept Africa's bull shark populations separated for 55,000 years.
When Turawa Hakeem caught a bull shark near Lagos, Nigeria last summer, the Ghanaian captain had no idea his crew was reeling a record winner onto his wooden fishing boat.
The eight-foot-long female had made an epic journey of at least 4,500 miles, the longest known movement of its species and the first time a bull shark was documented swimming through two oceans. The shark traveled from the M‚Ä¶

entry.title: Frozen shoulder is a real condition‚Äîand it mostly affects women
entry.summary:
Frozen shoulder is straightforward‚Äîthe condition means stiffness and difficulty in raising the arm. It can be caused by partial tears in the shoulder's tendon, as represented in this MRI scan. The painful affliction known as adhesive capsulitis can last for years‚Äîbut has long been ignored by medical researchers who doubted its existence. New treatments may finally promise a cure.
Stirrups, Pap smears, prenatal checks: At her busy office at Duke Women‚Äôs Health in Durham, NC, OB-GYN¬†Anne Ford‚Äôs work with female patients of all ages usually takes place from the waist down.
But Ford has noticed that a subset of her patients‚Äîall women entering or past menopause‚Äîcome to their appointments with a seemingly non-gynecological issue: adhesive capsulitis or ‚Äúfrozen shoulder,‚Äù a poorly un‚Ä¶

entry.title: These intimate safari camps offer a peek into Maasai culture
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúSimba!‚Äù The urgent whisper ‚Äî ‚Äòlion‚Äô in Swahili ‚Äî comes from Julius Naurori as he stands bolt upright in the back of our 4WD like a human antenna.
Immediately, our guide in the front slows the car to a cautious prowl and a hush descends, save for the tinkling silver discs tied to Julius‚Äôs waist as they sway in time with the rocking of the car. The dawn sky is still blushing crimson, and at first it‚Äôs hard to see what‚Äôs almost directly in front of us: four sleeping lions, their chocolate manes camouflaged as they lie on their sides in long, unruly grass marking the banks of the Mara River.
Our guide is Roca River Camp co-owner Ross Withey, and Julius, our wildlife-spotter, is his wingman on this safari drive in‚Ä¶

entry.title: These remote desert oases are Egypt‚Äôs hidden gems
entry.summary:
Siwa Oasis, a 12-hour drive from Cairo, is worth the trip to swim and float in hundreds of salt lakes and natural hot springs. Most visitors never experience the natural masterpieces that lie off the tourist trail‚Äîfrom bubbling hot springs to unearthly landscapes of dead volcanoes to the ‚ÄúValley of the Whales.‚Äù
The world knows Egypt for the Pyramids of Giza and cosmopolitan Cairo, the tourist-trodden temples of Luxor, and Red Sea resort towns. These coastal and Nile River Valley destinations are a narrow view of a country that‚Äôs 90 percent desert.
Few travelers venture into that 90 percent. The vast Western Desert, which blends into Libya and beyond, is Egypt‚Äôs great unknown. Adventurers since Alexander the Great have braved the harsh clime and been rewarded with the untouched‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN aims to transform urgency into action at Nice Ocean Conference
entry.summary: Countries are uniting in the French city of Nice next month to save the marine environment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Exponential rise in synthetic drug production and trafficking in the Golden Triangle
entry.summary: The Golden Triangle ‚Äì the remote, jungle-covered border region where Thailand, Myanmar, and the Lao People‚Äôs Democratic Republic meet ‚Äì has seen an exponential surge in the illicit manufacture and trafficking of synthetic drugs.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sanctions relief for Syria offers ‚Äòpowerful message of hope,‚Äô says UN migration agency
entry.summary: The UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) has welcomed recent decisions by the United States, the United Kingdom and the European Union to ease sanctions against Syria.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan conflict triggers regional health crisis, warns WHO
entry.summary: As the war between rival militaries in Sudan continues, the World Health Organization (WHO) has raised alarm over the escalating health emergency, driven by ongoing violence, mass displacement, collapsing health systems and poor conditions inside refugee camps.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New judge elected to the International Court of Justice
entry.summary: A seasoned diplomat and legal scholar from Jordan was elected on Tuesday to serve as a judge at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), the United Nations‚Äô principal judicial body.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Real cost of disasters is 10 times higher than previously thought, says UN
entry.summary: As countries face increasingly steep bills from natural hazards, the true cost of disasters is actually 10 times higher than previously estimated, with far-reaching effects across healthcare, housing, education and employment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN agencies calls for aid ‚Äòsurge‚Äô as Israeli distribution plan begins
entry.summary: Reports indicated on Tuesday that Israel‚Äôs controversial aid distribution plan had begun in Gaza as the United Nations called once again on the Israeli authorities to allow an ‚Äúimmediate surge‚Äù in the amount of supplies reaching the enclave to prevent starvation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Marketplace for government agencies to buy all the personal data about Americans
entry.summary: For the Intercept, Sam Biddle reports on government plans for a one-stop shop‚Ä¶ Tags: Intercept, privacy

entry.title: Undisclosed surveillance with facial recognition in New Orleans
entry.summary: For The Washington Post, Douglas MacMillan and Aaron Schaffer report on a system‚Ä¶ Tags: facial recognition, privacy, Washington Post

entry.title: 8 of the best beach cities in Spain
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
High-spirited northern surf hubs, relaxed Mediterranean-fronting neighbourhoods and glowing sands washed by the thundering Atlantic ‚Äî mainland Spain‚Äôs cities can offer all of this and more. Take your pick of these varied urban beauties, scattered around the country‚Äôs 3,000-mile peninsular coast. Beaches in Spain can get packed everywhere during the high season, from July to August, so for the best chance of solitude and space, it‚Äôs worth travelling in the quieter shoulder periods.
A pair of wide gold beaches, tucked into a crescent-moon bay between forested headlands, sets the scene for one of northern Spain‚Äôs most popular coastal escapes. Many San Sebasti√°n strolls begin on the promenade curving past Playa de On‚Ä¶
